questions.question: Inspector Clawson needs to optimize his patrol route. If he can visit 3 locations in 2 hours, how many locations can he visit in 8 hours?
questions.explanation: Rate = 3 locations/2 hours = 1.5 locations/hour. In 8 hours: 1.5 Ã— 8 = 12 locations. The Inspector's optimization!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles invests $1000 at 5% annual interest. How much will he have after 3 years?
questions.explanation: Compound interest: A = P(1 + r)^t = 1000(1.05)Â³ = 1000(1.157625) = $1157.63. Professor Tinkles' investment growth!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's garden has a rectangular area of 200 mÂ². If the length is 20m, what's the width?
questions.explanation: Area = length Ã— width, so 200 = 20 Ã— width, therefore width = 10m. Lady Pawsington's garden geometry!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth's car travels 240 miles in 4 hours. What's his average speed?
questions.explanation: Speed = distance/time = 240 miles/4 hours = 60 mph. Sir Whiskersworth's velocity calculation!

questions.question: A population of cats grows from 100 to 150 in 2 years. What's the annual growth rate?
questions.explanation: Growth rate = (150-100)/100 = 50/100 = 0.5 over 2 years. Annual rate = 0.5/2 = 0.25, but using compound: (1.5)^(1/2) - 1 â‰ˆ 0.22. Population modeling!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson analyzes crime data. If 60% of cases are solved in 24 hours, how many cases out of 50 will be solved quickly?
questions.explanation: 60% of 50 = 0.6 Ã— 50 = 30 cases. The Inspector's statistical analysis!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles needs to mix solutions. If he has 2L of 20% acid and 3L of 30% acid, what's the final concentration?
questions.explanation: Total acid = (2 Ã— 0.20) + (3 Ã— 0.30) = 0.4 + 0.9 = 1.3L. Total volume = 5L. Concentration = 1.3/5 = 0.26 = 26%. Professor Tinkles' chemistry!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's library has 500 books. If 40% are fiction, how many are non-fiction?
questions.explanation: Non-fiction = 100% - 40% = 60%. 60% of 500 = 0.6 Ã— 500 = 300 books. Lady Pawsington's library statistics!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth's business has fixed costs of $2000 and variable costs of $5 per item. What's the total cost for 100 items?
questions.explanation: Total cost = Fixed + Variable = $2000 + ($5 Ã— 100) = $2000 + $500 = $2500. Sir Whiskersworth's cost analysis!

questions.question: A temperature model shows T(t) = 20 + 5t, where t is hours. What's the temperature after 3 hours?
questions.explanation: T(3) = 20 + 5(3) = 20 + 15 = 35Â°C. Mathematical modeling in action!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson's evidence shows a 15% increase in cases each month. If he starts with 20 cases, how many will he have after 2 months?
questions.explanation: After 1 month: 20 Ã— 1.15 = 23. After 2 months: 23 Ã— 1.15 = 26.45. The Inspector's exponential growth!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles' class has 30 students. If 70% pass the exam, how many students pass?
questions.explanation: 70% of 30 = 0.7 Ã— 30 = 21 students. Professor Tinkles' educational statistics!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's recipe calls for 2 cups of flour for 4 servings. How much flour for 10 servings?
questions.explanation: Rate = 2 cups/4 servings = 0.5 cups per serving. For 10 servings: 0.5 Ã— 10 = 5 cups. Lady Pawsington's culinary math!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth's investment grows by 8% annually. If he invests $5000, what's the value after 2 years?
questions.explanation: A = P(1 + r)^t = 5000(1.08)Â² = 5000(1.1664) = $5832. Sir Whiskersworth's compound interest!

questions.question: A survey shows 45% of cats prefer fish, 35% prefer chicken, and 20% prefer beef. If 200 cats were surveyed, how many prefer fish?
questions.explanation: 45% of 200 = 0.45 Ã— 200 = 90 cats. Survey data analysis!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson's case load increases by 10 cases per week. If he starts with 50 cases, how many will he have after 4 weeks?
questions.explanation: Linear growth: 50 + (10 Ã— 4) = 50 + 40 = 90 cases. The Inspector's workload modeling!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles' tea temperature cools from 80Â°C to 60Â°C in 10 minutes. What's the cooling rate?
questions.explanation: Cooling rate = (80-60)/10 = 20/10 = 2Â°C per minute. Professor Tinkles' thermal analysis!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's garden produces 5 tomatoes per plant. If she has 12 plants, how many tomatoes total?
questions.explanation: Total tomatoes = 5 Ã— 12 = 60. Lady Pawsington's agricultural math!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth's car depreciates by 15% each year. If it's worth $20,000 now, what will it be worth in 2 years?
questions.explanation: Value after 1 year: 20000 Ã— 0.85 = 17000. After 2 years: 17000 Ã— 0.85 = 14450. Sir Whiskersworth's depreciation!

questions.question: A population model shows P(t) = 1000e^(0.02t). What's the population after 5 years?
Inspector Clawson's success rate is 85%. If he investigates 20 cases, how many will he solve?
questions.explanation: 85% of 20 = 0.85 Ã— 20 = 17 cases. The Inspector's success statistics!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles' class attendance is 90% on average. If 25 students are enrolled, how many typically attend?
questions.explanation: 90% of 25 = 0.9 Ã— 25 = 22.5 students. Professor Tinkles' attendance analysis!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's recipe scales linearly. If 2 cups serve 4 people, how many cups for 6 people?
questions.explanation: Rate = 2 cups/4 people = 0.5 cups per person. For 6 people: 0.5 Ã— 6 = 3 cups. Lady Pawsington's scaling!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth's business profit is P(x) = 50x - 1000, where x is items sold. How many items for $2000 profit?
questions.explanation: 2000 = 50x - 1000, so 3000 = 50x, therefore x = 60 items. Sir Whiskersworth's profit optimization!

questions.question: A data set has mean 50 and standard deviation 10. What percentage of values are between 40 and 60?
questions.explanation: This is within 1 standard deviation of the mean, which contains approximately 68% of data in a normal distribution. Statistical analysis!
